instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with no liquid damage, no drop history.
Battery would be recognized and would stay at 0% (customer said it wasn't booting). Reflowed <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> as per Duke's advice in another thread. Battery immediately displayed correct voltage.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on Charger without Battery: 12.59v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on charger WITH battery: starts at like 11.5v and climbs up.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without Charger and ONLY battery: 11.1v

The computer now runs off the battery, shows a percentage too. However the percentage jumps around a bit.

My question is, does <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> being not even 12v while on the battery indicate that there is something else wrong? Or should I call this done?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message: Sounds like a battery issue. If the battery is charging and holding a charge, DO NOT replace it as all the batteries available are Chinese GARBAGE.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message: Gotcha, I'm a little worried right now because it black screened during an OS installation, so I'm hoping it's not <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> that just went bad. After restarting it's installing again, we'll see what happens. I'm going to stress test it to make sure I don't get any graphics issues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message: Yeah that issue could be battery as well, but also could be <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> or a graphics issue. Hopefully not let us know if it goes through

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message:
"My question is, does <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> being not even 12v while on the battery indicate that there is something else wrong?"
When both battery and charger are connected, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will drop, accordingly with actual charge of battery.
It will slowly increase until battery gets fully charged 100%.
Then <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will jump again to 12.6V and Magsafe light will turn green.

If you got some reaction after reflowing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, change it now.
Resolder all its pads at least...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wasn't recognizing battery & <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't quite right?
threads.message: informaticos that was the answer I was looking for, thank you so much! I changed <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> just to be safe earlier, but that makes a ton of sense. Thank you. We should probably close this and marked solved.
